Anonymous Sun 30 Sep 2018 04:44:35 No.18565218 Report
Quoted By: >>18565555 >>18566623 >>18566646
>>18563167
>>18563921
Hey guys, Jacklin here. Thank you for your kind words. I always like hearing feedback for my work. I'm in bed phoneposting now, but I have to resist the urge to turn my laptop back on and keep writing.

Truth is originally Have You Seen the News came from a place of great ego and vanity. I had conceived of the basic idea long before writing it, right when the writefags here were at their apex of talking about world-building before it kinda simmered out. I was pretty much consuming everything that was being written and liking the vast majority of it. I asked myself "how would all these characters and their waifurs react if they saw THIS on the news?" I then started drafting out the news story in question and it naturally evolved beyond its shallower intentions. I still do have some sort of sick fanboy mentality where I imagine how the characters from a Socks or Strong story (or any of the writefags) would react if they saw that news report. Or hell, how would any of you react if you listened to that on 60 minutes or something. The title is more than just a hint to the ending, it's asking you, the reader, a question: Have You Seen the News?

I'm sorry for that little tangent, I hope I didn't ruin any of the magic the story has for you. I generally just like to post updates to my current work and leave any other posting anonymous. But I've been thinking back on this and wanted to get it out of my system.
Anonymous

Anonymous Sun 30 Sep 2018 06:08:48 No.18566350 Report
Quoted By: >>18572105
>>18565729
Experiment with it and try to feel out which style works best with the sort of content you want to write. Some thoughts and scenes are harder to convey in greentext, whereas prose is always reliable. I prefer prose, but I'm giving greentexting a try because I've never attempted writing the sort of story I'm working on in that style. I can say, prose is definitely more comfortable.

If you've read A Roo'd Awakening, you'll notice that Comfy switches from greentexting to updating his story entirely in prose. Jacklin conveys HYStN's last scene in prose. Plenty writers shuffle back and forth, others stick to greentexting because they're comfortable with that medium, and other good writefags have never uploaded a greentext story.

>"I didn't think that would have such a bittersweet ending though," she says, eyes shifting away from the screen of her too large TV once the PawTube clip of a viral news report ends. Her frowning gaze catches your eye and eats at your heart.
>"Things are fucked like that," you weakly reply, holding your girlfriend, as of a week ago, just a bit closer. "You okay?"
>"I hate the news," she says, resting the chin of her muzzle on your shoulder. "And I really hate sad endings."
>"At least those two are still together," you say, realizing too late how dark that sounds.
>She tilts her head, regarding you with a hint of curiosity. "You're religious?"
>"Not quite? I believe that their spirits are still together, but maybe I'm being dumb."
>A thin smile cracks her sad expression. "I don't think that's dumb," she says, smile deepening, "I think it's romantic. Even if that's still a sad story, what you said gives me a bit of hope."
>"First time I've been accused of being romantic," you tell her, petting her feathery neck, "Not that I'll complain if it gets that sad look out of your gorgeous eyes."
>She chuckles. "You are total romantic. Call me a doof but I lo-" she is cut off by the next clip deciding to start up. The long delay makes no sense to you but what do you know, you always liked circuitry not software.
>"Stupid autoplay," she grumbles, pulling away from you to fiddle with the remote and stop another video about the same news story continuing. She's had enough of that, and you've definitely had enough. You have enough messed up thoughts without looking at the news.
>She turns off the TV and places the remote on the table, then pulls you into a hug. "Forget it," she mutters, nuzzling your nose.
>"Forget what?" you ask.
>"Krasna and, uh, HER Anon. I'll believe what you do, that they're still together in the next life."
>"So you're religious?"
>"Nope." Anya kisses your nose. "I just believe you do what little you can, even if it's hope."

10/10 love it. Actually went on a reading binge this week and your story was one of them.
>>18565555
I'm afraid I can't really delve into how I write without getting personal And this place ain't no blog. I will say that the key to good writing is constant reading. Have a book to read all the time. When I was a kid I was reading at least 5000 words a day and absorbing it. Your brain will subconsciously know the basics to good writing if you read work you enjoy.

As far as greentext Vs prose go, I don't think it's fair for me to answer that. I've been studying and writing metered poetry for years now, to the point that writing in meter is easier for me than prose. The greentext is just an extension of that, allowing me to give a lot of information and emotional weight with the fewest amount of words. It's strange and it's always hard to explain. I will say that for those who are going greentext, you really have to embrace the fractured sentence, which is a tough thing to balance against making sure everything else is fine grammatically. Which many in this general have pointed out time and time again that is not the case, much to their annoyance.
Anonymous

It's different with writing though. You should have high standards for Grammer and spelling but standards for execution whether it's rendering or how the author conveys actions in the story are subjective. Lightening in the bottle is short yet has great rendering and is still able to convey similar feelings of passion as Have you seen the news.
>>18570780
Comfy is comfy. He's switched to prose recently, maybe in his next story he'll switch up his writing to be more action based but still keeping that comfy feel.

Anonymous Sun 30 Sep 2018 17:21:17 No.18571935 Report
Quoted By:
>>18571412
Because in a sci-fi story it's the world that is spectacular, not the people within it. Superhero or modern fantasy settings normally make the protagonists special, elevated above the common folk by having some kind of powers or supernatural abilities while the characters from most sci-fi stories can be transplanted into a modern, down-to-earth setting with very little changes needed - the difference between Han Solo and Superman, for example.

This means that sci-fi stories primarily revolve around how 'normal' people interact with each other and the high-tech world around them rather than focusing on how inherently special the characters are, which makes it much harder to fall into the Mary Sue trap when writing them (especially given the amateur nature of /hmofa/'s scribblings).
Anonymous

  • Report

>>18579414
I'm a writer, Anon. I know exactly what he's talking about. You're about half-right, though I wouldn't necessarily commit to a masturbatory tragedy just for the sake of torturing my characters. Actually... I probably would, tbhwyfam. In any case, love is more meaningful with struggle, when there's a fight to be won, when the happy ending you're absolutely parched for midway through a story comes to fruition unexpectedly. There's nothing more satisfying than that journey. But even more tantalizing and torturous is the struggle to bind and keep their forbidden union against external forces.

It's for your readers to be stressed out from your writing, needing to take intermittent breaks to walk around or do something else, just to inevitably return for more triumph and punishment.

>Means a lot to hear I'm doing things right with the story
You're doing very well with it. Don't deviate from your vision for Roo'd. The POV switches are good, though I was originally on the fence about it easing the readers' blue balls too much. >>18580844
We've talked some about it before. MO deserved the bustle it stirred up because it bucked a trend and made alternative and darker stories acceptable in the itt. Your story read well, but was pretty experimental. It's hard breaking down a year of events happening within a single confined pace, and time-jumps are a decent way to resolve that, especially within a short story. Some of it seemed repetitive, but you cranked up he frustration well in readers by adapting protag' to become the sort of patient fighter that waits for the perfect time to conquer his enemy, while throwing an ethical curveball into the mix that was more than just a moral dilemma, you made it biological. That aspect of MO came to dominate its conclusion, and you make that tangible in AI. My only concerns are with the psychology of protag' being difficult to wrap around without some major external influence beyond Anna, but that's an aside for now. I'm looking forward to more of that story.

Anonymous Mon 01 Oct 2018 03:36:07 No.18582249 Report
Quoted By: >>18583523
>>18571486

Especially if you're actually part way through writing it, don't let some constructive criticism keep you from completing your story. Just try to be mindful of the watch outs presented above. If you're going to make your story serious, you need to focus hard on what actually sparks the love interest between characters while trying to keep things as relate-able as possible. A good example of this would be an anon (or waifur) working on some boring part of a larger project and their opposite being part of a clan contracted to wipe out the whole project team. Something stays the ninja's blade and the story plays out around how the ninja keeps the worker drone on this side of the mortal plane.

Alternately, if you're going to actually go full Mary-Sue character, you might as well go full-ham and avoid any pretensions of being serious. A full-on cartoon story with some soli comfy written in - or some lighthearted lewd goodness can work wonders (can be super explicit, just don't try to make it serious - that's where cringe lives). Think of it this way. No one likes the kid who rocks up to a car show talking about how awesome his riced out Civic is. Everyone (with a sense of humor, at least) can appreciate the guy/gal who rocks up in a super riced out shit-box, but has a sense of humor about the various played-out things they've done to ruin their car.

Anonymous Mon 01 Oct 2018 04:42:26 No.18583407 Report
Quoted By:
>>18582868
>**to great acclaim
>eff

LOL, I appreciate the late catches, and glad to see I'm not the only person who gets bothered by derking up something on a 4chan post.

As far as technical writing goes, it's safe money, but not something I'd consider super exciting. I'm in product engineering, and write mostly design reviews, process instructions, and the odd journal (company internal) on tailoring testing to better match field use.

It's nice insofar as what you're writing about comes extremely easy and the process (...for writing about process) is extremely formulaic (Say what you're going to say. expound upon what you're saying, say what you said, massive appendix full of technical references).

The problem with it, is that there's not a whole hell of a lot of imagination or opportunities to mix up writing styles. You can put some humor into your documents, but it's an extremely fine balancing act to keep things esoteric enough that only the right people get it, while keeping it accessible enough that folks don't just think you're weird (...or moreso than they already do).
...also, character/word building are right out. I've always loved building universes in my own head, but have never been that great about following through (and as I'm sure you know, they never seem quite as good in the cold light of reality, as opposed to the rose tinted lens of the mind's eye.)
